0--> More people work for  Walmart than live in  Slovenia.
1--> After an  Islamic cleric blamed women who dress provocatively  for earthquakes in 2010,  100,000 women joined for a  "Boobquake" to test the theory. Nothing happened.
2--> Google has a  comprehensive timeline of  everything you do with their products, called "My Activity", including websites you visited with Chrome, YouTube Videos, Music and apps you use on your Android.
3-->White tigers carry a gene that is only present in around 1 in every 10,000 tigers. 
4--> American  commuters collectively waste  5.5 billion hours per year in  traffic, releasing into the atmosphere an unnecessary 56 billion pounds of CO2.
5--> Fidel  Castro took personal  responsibility for the  persecution suffered by  homosexuals in Cuba.
6--> A recent study estimates that mass-adoption of  self-driving cars could  reduce over  90% of traffic accidents.
7--> The  Navy once  delivered mail for the Post Office via  missile.
8--> The Illacme tobini is a  millipede that has  414 legs, no eyes, 200 poison glands, and  four penises.
9--> One-third of  Chinese women have  never heard of  tampons.
10--> Buzz  Aldrin's first words on the Moon were  "Beautiful view."
11--> Prisoners who maintain a positive relationship with their  children are 6 times  less likely to reoffend.
12--> In 1798, Napoleon invaded Rome, arrested Pope Pius VI, and imprisoned him in France where he died a year later.
13-->9% of Americans have used their  phones during sex and 12% in the shower. 
14--> Charles Darwin married his first  cousin and had 10 children. 3 died as infants and 3 were infertile. He was the  first to raise the question if  incest may cause weaknesses in offspring after studying inbred plants in his garden.
15-->170 Swiss troops accidentally invaded Liechtenstein in 2007 after getting lost during a training exercise.
16--> Narcissistic Personality Disorder often co-exists with  depression or anxiety, which is typically the  only reason a narcissist  tries therapy.
17--> Infamous crime boss  Al Capone played music and  wrote a love song while he was  in Alcatraz.
18--> The death of a loved one makes you up to 21 times more likely to suffer a heart attack within a day of your loss.
19--> In  1970, America had over  50,000 pay toilets. By 1980, there were almost none.
20--> Venting your  anger online only makes you  angrier, a study found.
21--> Humans aren't nutritious, so ancient cannibals probably devoured humans for other reasons.
22--> Babies in Britain, Canada and  Italy cry more than elsewhere, says an International study.
23--> The phenomenon where the  shower curtain randomly  clings to you, it's called the  shower-curtain effect.

25--> The  USA. and  Russia still have thousands of tons of  chemical weapons.
26--> Author  Ray Bradbury was  so poor growing up that he borrowed the  suit with a bullet hole his uncle was murdered in for his high school graduation ceremony.
27--> Fewer dopamine receptors in the brain are associated with a higher  preference for  sweets in adults of normal weight.
28--> The  Republic of Benin was independent for  less than a day.
29--> In the US, if you are  delayed by an airline for more than 4 hours for actions within their control (overbooking), you are  entitled to 4 times the face vale of the ticket, capped at $1300.
30--> Honey has  antiseptic properties due to its ability to produce hydrogen peroxide within. 
31--> The Democratic Republic of the  Congo is the  most populated officially  Francophone country, not France. 
32--> Less than 10% of tiger's hunts end successfully.
33--> Machu Picchu wasn't known to the world until a  Yale Professor , Hiram Bingham,  re-discovered it in  1911.
34-->Deforestation rates in Africa  are twice  the average. More than 4 million hectares (9.9m acres) of forest are lost every year.
35-->Tardigrades  are the most durable of known organisms, withstanding temperature ranges from −458 °F (−272 °C) to 300 °F (150 °C), and pressures 6 times greater than those found in the deepest ocean trenches.

41--> There's a book called  "Everything men know about a women" that is just  120 blank pages.

563--> A swarm of  20,000 bees once  followed a car for two days because their queen was trapped inside the car. 
564--> Archaeologists discovered a  2400-year-old mosaic skeleton that says  "Be cheerful and live your life."
565--> The  Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum offers  audio tours in Klingon, a fictional language from Star Trek. 
566--> Google delisted 1.75 billion websites because of copyright takedown requests. 
567--> Unlike other religions, the  Dalai Lama urges spiritual seekers  not to convert to Tibetan Buddhism, but to remain with their own religions. 
568--> If the Ancient Persians decided something while drunk, they had a rule to reconsider it when sober. If they made a decision sober, they would reconsider it while drunk.
569--> Pablo Escobar's son says he  offered himself as a  consultant to Netflix in order to present facts as they actually happened on "Narcos", but the director declined his offer. 
570--> In 2013,  after more than  20 years of soda being America's number one beverage,  water has taken over as  Americans' favorite drink.

575--> More than 60% of pandas born in captivity die within a week.
576--> The  big toe carries the most weight of all the toes, bearing about  40% of the  load.
577--> Only 1 in 10 victims of cyber-bullying tell a parent.
578--> If you weighed  150 lbs. (68 kg.) on  Earth, you would weigh  159 lbs. (72 kg.) on  Saturn.

597--> The life span of tigers in the wild is thought to be about 10 years. Tigers in zoos live twice as long.

599--> As a teenager,  Steve Jobs traveled to  India to seek enlightenment and returned as a  Buddhist.

601--> 40% of corn is used for  ethanol to add to fuel. Another  40% is used for  livestock feed.

604--> Red Bull was created in Thailand in 1976 as an energy drink  for truck drivers.

609--> In the 1980s, a  one letter typo cost the Yellow Pages  US$10 million when they misprinted a travel agency's advertisement for 'exotic vacations" as  "erotic vacations."

624--> For 2 years during WW1, the Big Ben's bells were silenced and the clock was not illuminated at night to avoid guiding attacking German Zeppelins.
625--> Up to 10% of invasive cancers are related to radiation exposure.
626--> Eddie Eagan is the only person to ever win gold medals in both the Winter and Summer Olympics: boxing and bobsled. 
627--> Jupiter doesn't orbit the  sun's center. It orbits a spot in empty space between it and the sun called the barycenter. 
628--> In  Korea, everyone is  one year old from the time they are  born, and everyone gets a year older on New Year's day. 
629--> An  inmate filed a US$5 million lawsuit against himself. He claimed that he violated his own civil rights by getting arrested. He then asked the state to pay because he has no income in jail. 
630--> In Victorian London, people were paid to collect dog poop. It was used to tan leather.
631--> Although it is said the Cuban Missile Crisis lasted for 13 days, it went on for 3 additional weeks.

633--> Rjukan (Norway) and Viganella (Italy) are both situated in deep valleys where  mountains block the sun's rays for up to 6 months every year, so they built  gigantic mirrors to reflect daylight downwards.

636--> Prince Charles and  Prince William never travel on the  same airplane. British Royal protocol is that two heirs should never fly on the same flight together so that the royal lineage is protected.

1118--> African  bongos eat  burned wood after lightning storms.
1119--> King George III's  urine was  blue.
1120--> RadiThor, an  energy drink sold in the 1920s, claimed it provided energy and cured a host of ailments, including impotence. It was simply  radium dissolved in water,  slowly killing its customers.
1121--> The 1960s US TV show  "Lost in Space" was  set in 1997.
1122--> In 2013,  Detroit temporarily  stopped issuing death certificates because it ran  out of paper.
1123--> There are more than  35 places called  Lebanon in the  USA. and no fewer than 50 Greenvilles.
1124--> There were once 9 subspecies of tigers: Bengal, Siberian, Indochinese, South Chinese, Sumatran, Malayan, Caspian, Javan and Bali. The last 3 are extinct, one is extinct in the wild, and the rest are endangered.
1125--> The African grey  parrot Alex was said to have the  intelligence of a human  5-year-old.
1126--> Amazon.com sold its  first book in July 1995: "Fluid Concepts and Creative Analogies."
1127--> Some users of  antidepressant Clomipramine have found that it causes the strange side effect of  orgasms after yawning.
1128--> Jean Cousin has been said to have discovered the  New World in 1488, four years before Christopher Columbus, when he landed in Brazil around the mouth of Amazon, but this remains unproven.
1129--> In 1992, a man fell to his death  at the Grand Canyon while failing to pretend to fall off  the railing.
1130-->Machu Picchu means "Old Peak" or "Old Mountain" in the Quechua  Indian language.
1131--> An Austrian fertility doctor fathered up to 600 children by using his own sperm to impregnate customers between 1943 and 1962. 
1132--> A  2-hour movie plus 5 minutes of previews uses  2.1 miles  (3.4 km) of 35mm film. 
1133--> Time magazine named  Gandhi the  Man of the Year in  1930. Later in 1938, they named Hitler. 
1134--> The average male would have to drink  149 cans of  Red Bull to  die from a  caffeine overdose. But it would vomit before drinking that much. 
1135--> Pigeons can be trained to  detect Cancer'>breast cancer
1136--> Happy cows produce  more milk, and simply the act of calling them by their name ups the production by an extra 3.5%

1138--> Coffee  has been found to  reverse liver damage caused by alcohol.
1139--> A ton of  iPhones yield  300 times more gold than a ton of  gold ore.
1140--> In 2016, a Dutch  woman who was  raped in  Qatar was  convicted of adultery, fined over US$800, and spent months in jail for reporting the crime. 
1141--> No country in the world has a  lower life expectancy than the the countries with the highest life expectancy in  1800.
1142--> Louis Armstrong spent his adult life celebrating the  wrong birthday. He believed it was July 4th, 1900, but it was actually August 4th, 1901. 
1143--> Sanitary pads can take 500 to  800 years to  decompose in landfills. 
1144--> The man who inspired the 2004 Tom Hanks movie  "The Terminal" spent  18 years living at the departure lounge of Charles de Gaulle  Airport.
1145--> Legends say  China began in a  great flood, some 4,000 years ago. Scientists found  geological evidence that the flood was real. 
1146--> A study in Canada found that people now have a  shorter attention span than goldfish, just 8 seconds. 
1147--> Being  attentive to your partner and making your partner  feel special will boost  sexual desire, a study found.

1159--> The  first transaction of  Bitcoins was to  buy pizza for 10,000 Bitcoins, which later increased in value to over  US$12 million.
1160--> The word  "music" comes from the  Muses, goddesses of the arts in Greek mythology. 
1161--> On the night of the D-Day invasion, only 15% of paratroopers landed in the right place.
1162--> Recycling a single run of the Sunday New York Times would save  75,000 trees.
1163--> The  average time it takes for a  new habit to stick is  66 days.
1164-->Xenoglossophobia is the fear of foreign languages.

1167--> Pandas are considered to be  endangered, with about  1,600 in the wild and another few hundred in captivity. 
1168--> Spiders can  get high and build different kinds of  webs while on weed, caffeine, mescaline and LSD. 
1169--> Wolverines are  trained to find and rescue avalanche survivors, because they are naturally inclined to  sniff out animals 20 feet below the snow and eat them. 
1170--> A  typo prevented hackers of stealing US$1 billion in 2016. They misspelled "foundation" as "fandation" in a wire transfer request, prompting bank authorities to investigate.

1173--> A dead adult male  tiger can sell for  US$10,000 or more on the  black market.
1174--> The Great Wall of China is being destroyed by farmers living around the structure who have been turning it into pathways, shelters and even fertilisers for crops. 
1175--> In  India, Snakes are worshipped as gods even today. Many women pour milk on snakes, despite snakes' aversion for it.
1176--> The are over 900 stone ring monuments in the British Isles. Stonehenge is just the most famous of them.

1266--> Our memories can be so easily manipulated that in just  3 hours you can be  convinced you committed a crime in your teenage years, a research found.

1300--> Is  Islamic law, money isn't allowed to generate more money by being put into a bank account or lent to someone else. Banks make their money by sharing the risk of their investments with investors, operating on a profit-loss basis.

1302--> Wine and steak taste good together because each are at the  opposite ends of the  sensory spectrum.

1656--> The Tree of Tenere was considered the most isolated tree on Earth, being the only one for 250 miles in the Sahara Desert, until a drunk driver hit it in 1973.
1657--> It took Victor Hugo  12 years to write the classic novel  "Les Miserables."
1658--> The  largest sea evacuation in the US happened on  9/11. Almost  500,000 people got evacuated by  boat in less than 9 hours. 
1659-->Over 77% of people surveyed in the US believe men should pay the bill on a first date. About 19% felt it should be split in some way.

1661--> Octopus blood is blue.
1662--> At  67 years old, a Polish adventurer made the longest open-water  kayak crossing of the Atlantic in history, going from  Lisbon to Florida in 6 months.

1664--> The last thing Elvis Presley ate before he died was four scoops of ice cream and 6 chocolate chip cookies.
1665--> In 2003, Steve Jobs sold his apartment in Manhattan to U2 singer Bono.
1666--> In 1835, an unemployed house painter  tried to  kill the US president  Andrew Jackson. Both killer's  pistols failed, and Jackson  beat his  attacker several times with a  walking cane.

1672--> In English,  zero quantities are plural by default. Therefore, you should write "0 results found."
1673--> The  Stendhal Syndrome is a disorder that causes rapid  heartbeat, dizziness, fainting, confusion, and even hallucinations when someone is  viewing a work of  art.

1686--> Doctors make a  correct diagnosis more than  twice as often as 23 commonly used  symptom-checker apps, a 2016 study found.

1923--> Philosopher  René Descartes is most well known for the saying  "I think, therefore I am," but he also developed the  XY-coordinate system.

1925--> The  1989 article that  proposed the acronym  LOL also  suggested using  ‘H' to mean  ‘Huh?'
1926--> In 1912, as a young man, former president of Vietnam  Ho Chi Minh worked as the  cook's helper on a ship bound for the US
1927--> Queen Elizabeth I owned at least  150 wigs.
1928--> 60% of Americans order food for takeout or  delivery at least  once a week.
1929--> Actor  Gene Wilder died at home while  listening to one of his favorite songs,  "Over the Rainbow" sung by Ella Fitzgerald.
1930--> The  first ballpoint pens in America sold for US$12.50, the equivalent of  US$164 today.
1931--> If you weighed  150 lb (68 kg) on  Earth, you would weigh  57 lb (26 kg) on  Mercury or  Mars.
1932--> "Surprise me" were the  last words of the 100 year-old, legendary comedian  Bob Hope, responding to his wife's question regarding where he would like to be buried.
1933--> September is the ninth month and the  only month with the  same number of letters in its name in English as the  number of the month.
1934--> At the time of his death,  Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi was one of the world's richest man,  worth US$200 billion.
1935--> There is a  stadium in Brazil in which the midfield line lies on the  Equator, making  each team defend one hemisphere.
1936--> Trey Parker,  co-creator of  "South Park," has a  signed photo of Saddam Hussein on his office wall.
1937--> People interrupt close  friends or family more than they interrupt strangers, a study found.
1938--> Spanish and  Brazilian women only spend about an  hour and a half a week on  housework, while  French women spend almost  no time on it.
1939--> The phrase  'crocodile tears' refers to a  medieval belief that crocodiles shed  tears of sadness when killing and  consuming their prey.
1940--> Kangaroos are almost always  left-handed.
1941--> Helium is the only element  discovered in space before it was found on  earth.
1942--> Before the  Columbian Exchange, there were  no oranges in Florida, no bananas in Ecuador, no potatoes in Ireland,  no coffee in Colombia, no pineapples in Hawaii, no rubber trees in Africa, no tomatoes in Italy, and  no chocolate in Switzerland.
1943--> The EU  banned cheese made in  Stilton to be called  Stilton cheese.
1944--> The  Nebra Sky Disc (1600 BC) is the earliest known space map and the  oldest known portable  astronomical instrument.
1945--> A group of  flamingos is called a  flamboyance.
1946--> The  letters Q, W, and X were  illegal in Turkey for 85 years.
1947--> Alfred Nobel, inventor of the dynamite, was  astonished to read  his own obituary, titled "The merchant of death is dead," in a French newspaper. It was Alfred's brother who had died, but the episode made him reconsider his legacy. His last will specified that his  fortune be used to  create the Nobel Prize.
1948--> Les Harvey,  guitarist for '70s blues-rock band Stone the Crows,  died onstage in front of 1,000 fans on May 3, 1972 when he was  electrocuted while tuning up for a show.
1949--> Orgia nova Fitch is the biological nomenclature for a  species of moth.
1950--> The  inventor of roller skates first  demonstrated them by hurtling into a party while playing the violin and  crashing into a huge mirror.
1951--> Eric Clapton grew up  believing his grandmother was his mother and  his mother was his sister.
1952--> The term  “checkmate” comes from the Arabic and ultimately Persian phrase  “shah mat” which means  “the king is dead.”
1953--> After the Crimean war, and until 1916, soldiers in the  British army were  required to sport  mustaches.
1954--> In the 19th century, doctors treated hysteria in women  by inducing orgasms. This is how the vibrator was invented. 
1955--> The Allies  parachuted dummies over  Normandy on D-day to  distract Nazi gunners from the real paratroopers. 
1956--> Tarantulas have evolved almost exactly the same shade of vibrant blue at least 8 separate times.
1957--> About  US$2 billion in  lottery prizes go  unclaimed every year in the US 
1958--> Neil Armstrong threatened legal action against his  barber for  selling his hair to a collector for  US$3,000.
1959--> Studies show  tattoos make it more  difficult to find skin cancer, since a malignant mole can take on the color of the tattoo surrounding it. 
1960--> There is an island known as "Just Room Enough Island" that has just enough room for a tree and a house.
1961-->Vegans  in the UK went from 150,000 in 2006 to 542,000 in 2016.
1962--> A female president's husband would be known as "First Gentleman".
1963--> Pocahontas was  11 years old when she met John Smith. He was 28.
1964--> “Derealization” is a dissociative phenomenon that causes the  external world to feel dreamlike. 74% of people have experienced it.
1965--> Easter will be on  April Fool's Day in 2018.
1966--> Christopher Columbus's strained relationship with the Spanish crown led to his arrest and dismissal as governor of the settlements on the island of Hispaniola in 1500.
1967--> All cats, including tigers, have a distinct scent associated with them due to their individualized scent glands. 
1968--> Crete has  40 million olive trees, around 60 per inhabitant.
1969--> In Gibraltar, where Jews have lived for about 650 years, there's a  special recipe for Passover's charoset replacing apples: the  dust of real bricks .
1970--> 100 million years ago,  6.5m-long primitive crocodiles were good swimmers but were also capable of  galloping across the plains. 
1971--> During a siege, the  Mongols catapulted corpses that were  infected with the plague over the city walls to infect the inhabitants.
1972--> Princess Leia's iconic  double-bun hairstyle was inspired by 'soldaderas',  Mexican revolutionary rebel fighters from the turn of the 20th century.
1973--> The temperatures near the site of the bomb blast during the  Hiroshima explosion were estimated to be  300,000°Celsius (540,000°Fahrenheit). That's 300 times hotter than the temperature bodies are cremated at.
1974--> Roman emperor Hadrian, in 117 AD, declared  attempted suicide by soldiers a form of desertion and made it a  capital offense.
1975--> Temperatures in the  Namib desert can reach as high as  60°C during the day and  below 0°C at night.
1976--> There are  more stars in the universe  than words ever uttered by all the humans who ever lived.
1977--> In  Ancient Greece, the normal size of a  jury was about  500 people. 
1978-->Classical music played in restaurants increases the amount people spend on wine, a study found.
1979--> Muslim-majority countries account for  75% of all fatalities from  terrorist attacks from 2001 to 2015. The US and Europe account for just 2.2%.
1980--> Strawberry leaves can be used to relieve  gastrointestinal distress and joint pain. They also contain iron, calcium and vitamin C.
1981--> Novelist Guy de Maupassant denounced the  Eiffel Tower as a "useless and monstrous" structure. He liked to eat his meals in the restaurant at the tower's base, as it was the only place where he didn't have to look at it.
1982--> Leonardo  Da Vinci was an accomplished  lyre player.
1983--> Dildo is a  town on the island of Newfoundland,  Canada.
1984--> Scientists believe there is a  ninth planet in our solar system that is roughly 10 times larger than Earth. They haven't been able to locate it yet but they know it's there because of its gravitational effects on other objects.
1985--> 90% of  rural Australians say their lives are already  affected by  climate change.
1986--> India's Chennai  airport ceiling
1987--> has  fallen down  66 times in the past few years.
1988--> In the US,  70% of  workers are  not engaged or actively disengaged, the cost of which is a productivity loss of around $500 billion per year.
1989--> George W. Bush used  nicknames on everyone, calling  Tony Blair "Landslide", Silvio Berlusconi "Shoes" and Jonathan Horn "Horny."
1990--> The  "IKEA effect" is the  tendency for people to place a disproportionately  high value on objects that they  partially assembled themselves, such as furniture from IKEA, regardless of the quality of the end result.
1991--> The  "17059 Elvis" is a  minor planet discovered in 1999 and named after the singer.
1992--> "The Da Vinci Code" book was  banned in 2004 in  Lebanon after Catholic leaders deemed it  offensive to Christianity.
1993--> Shyness is an  evolutionary adaptation: whereas the braver animals may find more mates and eat more food, the shyer individuals, hiding on the sidelines, might  avoid attack.
1994--> Piranhas only attack you if you  mess with them or their eggs.
1995--> Data scientists analyzed 10,222 words to discover the  "happiest" word in the English language. It's  "laughter."
1996--> In 2015, a host of big food brands, led by Nestlé, vowed to use only natural flavors in products marketed in the US, just as a  shortage of natural vanilla was emerging.
1997--> Philosophical presentism is the view that neither the  future nor the past exist, only the present.
1998--> There is an  army recruitment lottery in Thailand. Every man over 21 has to participate. A red card means you have to go, a black card means you don't.
1999--> 88% of businesses believe  school leavers are unprepared for the world of work, according to a British Chambers of Commerce survey.
2000--> Abraham  Lincoln loved cats and once let one  eat from the table during a formal  White House dinner.
2001--> During WWII, a British  sailor escaped his submarine from depths of  270 feet (82 m) and managed to get to the surface and survive.
2002--> The US government gave Indiana University  $1 million to  study memes.
2003--> Saddam Hussein's son owned an actual  iron maiden and used it against people he didn't like.
2004-->20% of Ugandans  believe in witchcraft.
2005--> It's  illegal to  fall asleep under a  hair dryer in Florida, even if you're the salon owner. 
2006--> Ancient Romans were a very bath-loving people. They typically frequented public  baths once a day.
2007-->Isaac Newton was born prematurely  on Christmas morning. He was given little chance of survival.
2008--> A  17-year-old created a mobile app and sold it to Yahoo for  US$30 million, becoming one of the  youngest self-made millionaires ever.
2009--> In terms of your health —not how you look or smell— you only really have to  shower once or twice a week.
2010--> It's  illegal to lie down and fall  asleep with your  shoes on in North Dakota. 
2011--> When  Michael Jackson was 21, he wrote a personal note  promising to re-invent himself as the  greatest entertainer of all time.
2012--> A  small town in Minnesota decided to  secede from the US in the 70s and  declared war because "it is much easier to get assistance as a foreign country, which we need badly." 
2013--> In 2011, a German graffiti artist painted a 250 square meter  bridge to make it look like it was made out of  Lego.
2014--> You can get  tetanus a  not just from a  rusty nail but also from a  perfectly clean one. It is caused by bacteria commonly found in soil, dust and animal feces.
2015--> In 2014, a man from Arizona  stole a diamond worth US$160,000 and  traded it for  US$20 of weed.
2016--> The  Axeman of New Orleans, a  murderer who terrorized the city in 1918 and 1919, spared any home that was  playing jazz, his favorite music.
2017--> A  honeybee has the  same amount of  hairs as a  squirrel: 3 million.
2018--> Fruit flies use hairs on their head and thorax to catapult dust off of them at  accelerations of up to  500 times Earth's gravity.
2019--> The  names of the  English rivers Avon, Axe, Esk, Exe and Ouse all mean  ‘river' or  ‘water' in various  ancient languages.
2020--> The  McHotDog is a hot dog available at McDonald's in Japan. 
2021--> The  female panda may only be fertile for a few days each year but during this period she will  mate dozens of times with multiple males. 
2022--> The  Star Wars lightsaber sound was made by combining the  hum of an idle  film projector and the  buzz from an old  TV set.
2023--> Six-pack abs indicate  nothing about your strength, your flexibility, your stamina, your speed, or your overall level of  health.
2024--> Search Engines can only access  0.03% of the  Internet. The rest is known as the  "deep web."
2025--> Some  non-redheaded men have  red beards because they have  one copy of the  MC1R gene. Two copies would make them fully redheads. 
2026--> You spend  10% of your waking  life blinking.
2027--> In 1898, Nikola  Tesla predicted  drone warfare.
2028--> At the peak of his power, infamous Medellin cartel boss  Pablo Escobar brought in an estimated  US$420 million a week in revenue. 
2029--> Sultan Moulay Ismail, who ruled Morocco in the 17th century, is said to have  fathered around 1000 children . 
2030--> Male ducks have been observed engaging in  necrophilic gay sex.
2031--> A British research study found that watching a horror film prior to viewing abstract art enhances the enjoyment of the art for most people. 
2032--> The  motto of Russia's  nuclear strike missile force is: "After us, it is  silence."
2033--> Every US president with a beard has been a Republican.
2034--> The number of  Americans who  don't read books has nearly  tripled since 1978. 
2035--> The  world's largest underwater volcano, Tamu Massif, is the  size of New Mexico.
2036--> Lenticular clouds are  rare formations that can  look like UFOs. They are formed when wind encounters an obstruction such as a mountain. 
2037--> The  Shenandoah salamander doesn't have lungs and  breathes through its  skin.
2038--> The average human will spend 6.8% of their lives socializing with someone they love, or the equivalent of around 1,769 days. 
2039--> The  Australian Plate is moving about 7 centimeters (2.8 inches) northwards every year. 
2040--> A UN report stated that  4 million people died in Indonesia as a result of famine and forced labor during the WW2 Japanese occupation.
2041--> Scientists have created a  functioning guitar the size of a  human blood cell.
2042--> Instead of "Once upon a time," many  Korean folktales begin with  "Back when tigers used to smoke..."
2043--> Microwave ovens were invented by accident. Percy Spencer was standing in front of an active radar set when he noticed the candy bar he had in his pocket had melted. 
2044-->Michael Jordan was fined US$5000  for every game that he wore Air Jordans, as the shoes violated NBA policies. But he made an estimated US$90 million in 2013 alone, mostly from NIKE.
2045-->162,719 pints  of Guinness beer are wasted  each year due to mustaches.

2047-->Penguins can't  taste sweet  or savory flavors, only sour and salty ones.

2055--> The South American revolutionary Simon Bolivar was, at various times,  president of Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and  Venezuela.
2056--> In  Italy, 13, is not an  unlucky number, but  17 is.

2061--> A popular way to  cure impotence in the 14th century was to wear your  trousers on your head for 24 hours. 
2062--> The  Atlantic salmon's sense of  smell is  1000 times greater than that of a  dog.
2063--> The world's  first traffic signal was short lived. Installed in London in 1868, it  exploded less than a month later, injuring its policeman operator. 
2064--> In 1846, California was ruled by Mexico and the settlers in protest declared the territory an independent country for only one month.
2065--> From 1901 to 2012, 863 Nobel Prizes were awarded. Only 43 women were recipients.
2066--> The  Pentagon had separate bathrooms for blacks and whites when it opened in 1943.
2067--> The  thorny devil lizard drinks water  through its  skin and has a false head on the back of its neck to confuse predators.
2068--> Stealthy Seagoers Octopuses are masters at flying under the radar,  changing their coloration and texture to match their surroundings in seconds.
2069-->Louis Armstrong  was arrested at the age of 11 and learned music while in detention for 18 months.

2071--> In  1571, the Spanish doctor Nicolas Monardes identified  smoking tobacco as a cure for more than 20 ailments, including  cancer.
2072--> There's a  brewery in Germany that's almost  1,000 years old. It has been in continuous operation since the year 1040.
2073--> The moveable metal type was not first used for the Gutenberg Bible. Korean and Chinese books were produced the same way centuries earlier.

2078--> Chinese scientist Tong Dizhou  cloned the first fish in the 1960s, but the Maoist government forced him to abandon his research and  become a janitor during the Cultural Revolution.

2081--> Switzerland only joined the  United Nations in  2002.
2082--> Meteorito is a Cabernet Sauvignon  wine that  was aged in a barrel with a  4.5-billion-year-old meteorite for a year.
2083--> For every dollar invested in sanitation and water, there is a $4.30 return in the form of reduced health care costs around the world. 
2084--> Dr. Seuss cheated on his  wife while she had  cancer. After finding out about the affair, she killed herself and Dr. Seuss married his mistress.
2085--> Within  48 hours of quitting smoking, your nerve endings begin to regrow and your senses of  smell and taste begin to  return to normal.

2088-->A 2014 study found that when commuters on trains and buses talked to strangers, their conversations made them happier.

2090-->5,000 years ago, watermelons were pale-green, and bitter. As watermelons were bred to become sweeter, their flesh slowly changed to red.

2111--> The historical Buddha was not obese. The  "chubby Buddha" or "laughing Buddha" is a  10th-century Chinese folk hero by the name of Budai.

2113--> The  French military actually has the  best military record in Europe. Out of 168 battles fought since 387BC, they have won 109, lost 49 and drawn 10.

9594-->Tigers are the only predators known to regularly prey on adult bears.
9595-->Contrary to popular belief, there are no wild tigers in Africa. Only in Asia.
9596-->Cats, from lions  and tigers  right down to domestic felines, cannot  taste anything sweet.
9597-->White tigers are prone to having crossed eyes (strabismus).
9598-->Tigers were declared extinct  in Cambodia  in 2016.
9599--> The Bengal Tiger is the national animal  of India.
9600--> Less than 10% of tiger's hunts end successfully.
9601-->Tigers wait until dark to hunt. Their night vision is six times better than that of humans.

9603--> Tigers that breed with  lions give birth to hybrids known as  "tigons" and "ligers."
9604--> Tigers can eat up to 60 pounds (27 kilograms) of meat in one night.
9605--> The life span of tigers in the wild is thought to be about 10 years. Tigers in zoos live twice as long.
9606--> Between 1800 and 2009,  tigers killed an estimated  373,000 humans.
9607-->White tigers carry a gene that is only present in around 1 in every 10,000 tigers. 
9608--> Unlike lions, tigers live solitary lives and mark their territories to keep others away.
9609-->Tiger cubs are vulnerable in their first few months, with mortality as high as 50%.
9610-->100,000 wild tigers roamed Asia a century ago, but today their numbers have fallen to around 3,200 due to poaching.
9611--> There were once 9 subspecies of tigers: Bengal, Siberian, Indochinese, South Chinese, Sumatran, Malayan, Caspian, Javan and Bali. The last 3 are extinct, one is extinct in the wild, and the rest are endangered.

9614--> Tigers can, and will,  take revenge on those who have wronged them.

9619-->rainforests.

9626--> has been in existence
9627--> for at least

9893--> Researchers Joseph and Charles Vacanti  grew a human "ear" seeded from implanted cow cartilage cells on the back of a living mouse to explore the possibility of fabricating body parts for plastic and reconstructive surgery.
9894--> A 2011 poll of nearly  1,000 biomedical scientists conducted by the science journal Nature found that more than  90% agreed that the  use of animals in research is  essential.
9895--> People in the United States eat 9 billion chickens and 150 million cattle, pigs and sheep annually, and we use around  26 million animals for research, 95% of which are rodents, birds and fish.
9896--> In 2010,  Minnesota used more cats for testing than any other state (2,703), New Jersey used the most dogs (6,077), and Massachusetts used the most primates (7,458).
9897--> 95% of  animals used in  experiments are  not protected by the federal Animal Welfare Act (AWA), which excludes birds, rats and mice bred for research, and cold-blooded animals such as reptiles and most fish.
9898--> The California Biomedical Research Association states that nearly  every medical breakthrough in the last 100 years has resulted directly from  research using animals.
9899--> The US Food and Drug Administration endorses the use of animal tests on cosmetics to "assure the safety of a product or ingredient." American women use an average of 12 personal care products per day.
9900-->Classical Greek culture, which flourished during the 5th to 4th centuries BC, had a powerful influence on the Roman Empire and provided the foundation of modern Western culture.
9901-->Ancient Greek democracy, the world's first, lasted for only 185 years.
9902--> Between 40% and 80%  of the population of Classical Athens were slaves.
9903--> At its economic height, in the 5th and 4th centuries BC, Ancient Greece was the most advanced economy in the world.
9904-->The Ancient Greeks exercised naked. 
9905--> Ancient Greece's boys  went to school  at the age of 7 if they lived in Athens, or went to the barracks  if they lived in Sparta.
9906--> In Ancient Greece, a crucial part of a wealthy teenager's education was a mentorship with an elder, which in a few places and times may have included pederastic love.
9907-->The word "school" comes from the ancient Greek for "free time."
9908-->In ancient Greek, the word "idiot" meant anyone who wasn't a politician.

10075-->More  people died in Auschwitz than the British and American losses of WW2 combined.
10076--> About 1 in 6 Jews killed in the Holocaust died at Auschwitz.
10077-->1.1 million people died during the four and a half years of Auschwitz's existence.
10078-->Auschwitz  was first constructed to hold Polish political prisoners, who began to arrive in May 1940.
10079--> 144
10080--> prisoners are known to have escaped from Auschwitz successfully.
10081-->Besides Jews, others deported to Auschwitz  included 150,000 Poles, 23,000 Romani and Sinti, 15,000 Soviet prisoners of war and 400 Jehovah's Witnesses.
10082-->Witold Pilecki, a Polish soldier, volunteered to be imprisoned in Auschwitz in order to gather information, escape and let the world know about the Holocaust.
10083-->Auschwitz's camp commandant Rudolf Hoss, was arrested in 1946, convicted of murder and hanged  at the camp.
10084--> About 60 million Reichmarks, equivalent to £125m today, was generated for the Nazi state by slave labour at Auschwitz during the Holocaust.
10085--> During the Holocaust, a Jewish woman exposed up to 3,000 hiding Jews to the Gestapo to save her family. Even after the Nazis sent her parents and husband to Auschwitz anyway in 1943, she continued to work for the Gestapo until 1945.
10086-->Of a total of about 7,000 staff at Auschwitz, only 750 were ever punished.
10087--> Josef Mengele's "scientific" experiments at Auschwitz often involved studies of twins. If one twin died, he would immediately kill the other and carry out comparative autopsies. 
10088--> The main camp of Auschwitz was like a small town, with its own staff canteen, cinema, theatre and grocery store.
10089--> Polish midwife Stanislawa Leszczynska helped pregnant  women in Auschwitz  deliver over 3,000 babies.
10090--> Antoni Dobrowolski, the oldest known survivor of Auschwitz, died aged 108 on October 21, 2012, in Poland.
10091--> In Auschwitz, an SS guard fell in love  with a Jewish prisoner. He saved her life multiple times and she testified on his behalf during his post-war trial.
10092--> The company that created Zyklon B, the gas that was used to kill millions of Jews in the Holocaust, still exists as a pest control company.
10093-->During the Holocaust, Jewish boxer Salamo Arouch was imprisoned at Auschwitz. He was forced to fight fellow prisoners; the losers were sent to the gas chambers or shot. He survived over 2 years and 200 fights until the camp was liberated.
10094-->Bayer, famous for producing aspirin, bought prisoners from Auschwitz  to use as research subjects for testing new drugs.
10095--> Psychiatrist  Viktor Frankl drew on his imprisonment at Auschwitz in writing  "Man's Search for Meaning," the base for Logotherapy.
10096--> On July 21, 1944, inmate Jerzy Bielecki dressed in an SS uniform and using a faked pass, managed to cross the Auschwitz's gate together with his Jewish girlfriend, Cyla. Both survived the war.
10097--> During a revolt  at the Auschwitz  Concentration Camp, a member of the SS was stabbed, then burned alive in a crematorium oven.
10098-->Anne Frank's father survived Auschwitz and died in 1980 of lung cancer.
10099--> After Auschwitz  became a museum in 1947, exhumation work lasted for more than a decade.
10100--> In 1942,  four Auschwitz inmates successfully  escaped by stealing  SS officer uniforms and driving a stolen  Nazi car through the camp's front gate.

10402--> A  bolt of lightning is  5 times hotter than the surface of the  sun.
10403-->There will be a 50% increase in lightning strikes by 2100 if global warming continues, according to a scientific report.
10404--> There is a persistent storm at Lake Maracaibo, Venezuela. Lightning  storms occur for about 10 hours a night, 140 to 160 nights a year, for a total of about 1.2 million lightning discharges per year.

10416--> Since 1900, there have been an average of 18 major earthquakes and one great earthquake per year.

10496--> While most penguins  are monogamous, they spend most of their year apart.
10497--> There are 17 to 20 species of penguins, depending on which scientist you ask.
10498--> Some prehistoric penguin species attained enormous sizes, becoming as tall or as heavy as an adult human.
10499--> The oldest  known fossil penguin species lived in the early Paleocene epoch 
10500--> of New Zealand,  about 62 million years ago.
10501-->Penguins can jump up to 6 feet (1.8 m) out of the water.
10502-->1 in 50,000 penguins are born with brown  rather than black plumage.
10503-->Penguins have an organ near the eye that filters salt from the water out of their system.
10504--> In order to discover that penguins sleep more deeply  in the afternoon, scientists crept up on sleeping penguins at different times of the day and poked them with a stick until they woke up.
10505--> The Emperor Penguin is able to dive to depths of over 500m and stay under water for up to 27 minutes.
10506-->Roles are reversed on Emperor Penguin: the Male incubates the egg while she goes out to feed.
10507-->Magellanic penguins  always return to same mate after solo journeys totalling 200,000 miles.
10508--> Scientists can locate colonies of Penguins from space just by looking for dark ice patches of penguin poop.
10509-->In 2008, Norway knighted a penguin.
10510--> In 2009, snipers were deployed in Australia to protect a colony of little penguins from predators.
10511--> There are no penguins
10512--> in the Arctic.
10513-->Seals like to have sex with penguins.
10514-->Penguins  generally only lay one brood. The exception is the little penguin, which can raise two or three broods in a season.
10515--> When penguin mothers lose a chick, they sometimes attempt to  "steal" another mother's chick.
10516--> The most northerly penguins live in the Galapagos Islands.
10517-->Penguins  are able to control blood flow to their extremities, reducing the amount of blood that gets cold, but still keeping the extremities from freezing.
10518-->It is illegal for US citizens to eat penguins.
10519--> Most penguins swim underwater at 4 to 7 mph.
10520-->Penguins spend about half  of their lives on land  and half in the oceans.
10521-->Penguins don't have teeth. Instead, they have backward-facing fleshy spines that line the inside of their mouths. 
10522--> Once a year, penguins replace their old feathers by new ones.
10523--> The largest  living species of Penguins  is the Emperor Penguin. They are about 1.1 m (3 ft 7 in) tall and weigh about 35 kg (77 lb).
10524-->Penguins can't  taste sweet  or savory flavors, only sour and salty ones.
10525--> The African penguin is also known as the  jackass penguin, due to its  donkey-like braying  sounds.
10526--> Many species of  penguins gift mates with  rocks.

10556-->million people of all ages around the world suffer from depression.

10581--> Learned helplessness is a condition in which a person suffers from a sense of powerlessness, arising from a traumatic event or persistent failure to succeed. It is thought to be one of the underlying causes of  depression.
10582-->Benjamin Franklin was born in Boston, Massachusetts, on January 17, 1706. He lived 85 years.
10583-->Benjamin Franklin, one of the Founding Fathers of the US, was also a leading author, printer, political theorist, politician, freemason, postmaster, scientist, inventor, civic activist, statesman, and diplomat.
10584--> Benjamin Franklin organised and was the first secretary of the American Philosophical Society. He was elected president in 1769.
10585-->Benjamin Franklin wrote "Fart Proudly", a scientific essay about farts.
10586-->Benjamin Franklin published a paper saying America's population growth was so fast, it would surpass Britain in 100 years. This alarmed British leadership and was a factor in their oppression of the colonies.
10587-->Benjamin Franklin attempted to abolish slavery already in 1790.
10588--> Benjamin Franklin was an advocate of "air baths", during which he would spend up to an hour reading  or writing in his house completely naked.
10589--> Benjamin Franklin
10590--> invented 
10591--> the bifocals eyeglasses 
10592--> in 1784.
10593--> When Benjamin Franklin  invented his own harmonica, it became so popular in Europe that Mozart and Beethoven composed music for it.
10594-->Benjamin Franklin made 8 voyages across the Atlantic Ocean and was the first to map the Gulf Stream.
10595--> Benjamin Franklin never patented any of his inventions. He reasoned that "we should be glad of an opportunity to serve others by any invention of ours; and this we should do freely and generously."
10596--> At the age of 11, Benjamin Franklin invented a pair of swim fins. He was later recognized by his induction into the International Swimming Hall of Fame.
10597-->Benjamin Franklin was inducted into the US Chess Hall of Fame in 1999.
10598--> Benjamin Franklin  had a major influence on the emerging science of demography. He was also a pioneer in the study of slave demography.
10599--> Benjamin Franklin  received honorary degrees from Harvard  and Yale universities.
10600--> In recognition of his work with electricity, Benjamin Franklin received the Royal Society's Copley Medal in 1753.
10601--> Benjamin Franklin's autobiography, begun in 1771 but published after his death, has become one of the classics of the genre.
10602--> In 1734, Benjamin Franklin edited and published the first Masonic book in the Americas.
10603-->"Rebellion to Tyrants is Obedience to God" was Benjamin Franklin's suggested motto for the Great Seal of the US
10604--> Benjamin Franklin  had an illegitimate son who remained loyal to the British and fled to London after the war. He stayed there for the rest of his life.
10605--> In 1781, Benjamin Franklin attended a concert in which he narrowly escaped death when the opera house caught fire and burned.
10606--> Benjamin Franklin's last words were, 
10607--> "A dying man can do nothing easy."
10608--> Benjamin Franklin lived his life by 13 rules which he called  "the 13 virtues." He wrote them when he was 20. 
10609--> In 1785,  Benjamin Franklin was the  richest person in the  United States.
10610--> Benjamin Franklin proposed a phonetic  alphabet that got  rid of the letters  C,J, Q, W, X, and Y, but the American public refused to adopt it.
10611--> When the  Declaration of Independence was being drafted, Benjamin  Franklin suggested that the word  "sacred" be  replaced with "self-evident" because he believed that the nation should be founded on reason, not faith.

10661-->Between 10 and 20 volcanoes are erupting somewhere on Earth every day.

10664-->There's a volcano in Indonesia that spews blue flames.

10670-->No other country in Europe has as many volcanoes as Italy: the peninsula stands on a fault line.

10675--> enough lava to fill 11 Grand Canyons.
